Here is the peer reviewed currently published data. Just as an aside ‚Ä¶ Probenecid is FDA approved for use in humans and is available by prescription. The difference here is this drug has been and continues to be rigorously tested against CoV-2. Over the counter ivermectin is not approved for human use::: not formulated for human use and is not an antiviral treatment. It has been tested against SARS CoV-2 and failed. Vaccination is still the best course of action to limit infection and spread of disease but drugs/
medications are needed for acute treatments in cases where individuals cannot be vaccinated or have not been vaccinated and/or vaccine failure occurs. Think of them as a fail safe.

column4:
Atlanta Journal
September 3::: 1984

Great moments in a would be father‚Äôs life

To my Son::: if I ever have one:

Kid::: I am writing this on September 3::: 1984. I have just returned from Athens::: where I spent Saturday watching the University of Georgia::: your old dad‚Äôs alma matter::: play football against Clemson.

While the events of the day were still fresh on my mind::: I wanted to recount them so if you are ever born::: you can read this and perhaps be able to share one of the great moments in your father‚Äôs life.

Saturday was a wonderful day on the Georgia campus. We are talking a blue::: cloudless sky::: a gentle breeze and a temperature suggesting summer‚Äôs end and autumn‚Äôs approach.

I said the blessing before we had lunch. I thanked the Lord for three things: fried chicken::: potato salad and for the fact he had allowed me the privilege of being a Georgia Bulldog.

‚ÄúAnd ::: Dear Lord:::‚Äù I prayed::: ‚Äúbless all those not as fortunate as I.‚Äù

Imagine my son::: 82:::000 people::: most whom were garbed in red::: gathered together gazing down on a lush valley of hedge and grass where soon historic sporting combat would be launched.

Clemson was ranked number 2 in the nation::: and Georgia::: feared too young to compete with the veterans from beyond the river::: could only dream::: the smart money said::: of emerging three hours hence victorious.

They had us 20-6 at the half::: son. A man sitting in front of me said::: ‚ÄúI just hope we don‚Äôt get embarrassed.‚Äù

My boy::: I had never seen such a thing as came to pass in the second half. Todd Williams threw one long and high::: and Herman Archie caught it in the end zone::: and it was now 20-13.

Georgia got the ball again and scored again::: and it was now 20-20::: and my mouth was dry::: and my hands were shaking::: and this Clemson fan who had been running his mouth the whole ballgame suddenly shut his fat face.

Son::: we got ahead 23-20::: and the ground trembled and shook::: and many were taken by fainting spells.

Clemson‚Äôs kicker::: Donald Igwebuike::: tied it 23-23 and this sacred place became the center of the universe.

Only seconds were left when Georgia‚Äôs kicker::: Kevin Butler::: stood poised in concentration. The ball rushed toward him::: and it was placed upon the tee a heartbeat before his right foot launched it heavenward.

A lifetime later::: the officials threw their arms aloft. From 60 yards away::: Kevin Butler had been true::: and Georgia led and would win 26-23.

I hugged perfect strangers and kissed a fat lady on the mouth. Grown men wept. Lightning flashed. Thunder rolled. Stars fell::: and joy swept through::: fetched by a hurricane of unleashed emotions.

When Georgia beat Alabama 18-17 in 1965::: it was a staggering victory. When we came back against Georgia Tech and won 29-28 in1978::: the Chapel bell rang all night. When we beat Florida 26-21 in the last seconds in 1980::: we called it a miracle. And when we beat Notre Dame 17-10 in the Sugar Bowl that same year for the national championship::: a woman pulled up her skirt and showed the world the Bulldog she had sewn on her underbritches.

But Saturday may have been even better than any of those.

Saturday in Athens was a religious experience.

I give this to you::: son. Read it and re-read it::: and keep it next to your heart. And when people want to know how you wound up with the name ‚ÄúKevin‚Äù let them read it::: and then they will know.

- Lewis Grizzard

The Savannah River Ecology Laboratory is a UGA research unit located on the Savannah River Site near Aiken::: SC. Since 1951::: the SREL has utilized research at all levels of ecological organization::: analyzing the impact of missions at the Savannah River Site on the environment.

Along with his fellow researchers::: associate professor Jim Beasley provides advanced hands-on learning to students investigating wildlife conservation. Both graduate and undergraduate students get the opportunity to learn techniques they need to develop into professionals and get wildlife jobs. https://t.uga.edu/7lY

column1:
Raise your hand if you remember registering for classes via scantron sheets in Memorial Hall!

üì∏ from Hargrett Library::: circa 1980s and early 1990s.
column3: My freshman year we registered at a place called Chicopee and after that at Memorial Hall. What a free-for-all nightmare the process was.
column4: I tried to explain to my incoming freshman how hard it used to be to get a schedule-\-\now they sit on the computer watching TV on their phones and add themselves to waitlists. And still::: they are stressed out.
column5: That is pretty much the way I registered for all of my classes in the old days. (BC) The problem was that they didn't update the sheets fast enough so sometimes classes were full already and then you would have to choose another class or get the professor to give you a seat waiver to stay in the class.
column6: My mother worked in the Registrar‚Äôs Office and did the Coliseum registration with the punch cards. I went to Chicopee a couple of times. Brutal.
column7: Started out registration at Memorial Hall and ended up senior year at Chicopee. Thank goodness it‚Äôs easier today.
column8: I went in with my own spreadsheet of classes and schedule in preparation for the dreaded yellow slip. It was a mission to me!
column9: In the 1960‚Äôs::: you went to the coliseum and walked around to tables and signed your name on a sheet of paper. When the names filled that sheet the class was closed. Waited in line forever just to get in the coliseum.
column10: It was so long ago. I can‚Äôt remember how I registered for classes. No scanners in my world.
column11: At UNL it was the Union Ballroom - what a nightmare. Fill out the sheet::: submit it::: wait::: get it back only to say that a class was full or there was a conflict wash::: rinse::: repeat.
column12: The awful feeling of getting a yellow card back instead of a schedule! Ugh! I think I‚Äôm still suffering PTSD!
column13: Yes and as you stood in line to the registrars office to submit your choices news would trickle through the line that a certain class was now full::: so then if that affected you::: you had to rearrange your entire schedule‚Ä¶these kiddos today have no idea.
column14: I used to enjoy the process after my freshman year. We would get so excited to see art 101 openings. Just one of the bureaucratic things that we learned to navigate with ease at a big state school.

column229: In 1994::: I registered via dial-up modem. I think I may have been the first to do so. I had explained to my academic adviser that I could not make it up for in person registration and she told me about a new system they were working on in the 'computer department'. The small group of people that would eventually become the IT department were working out of a garage bay just off of East Campus Rd. They gave me a shoe box full of 4.25" disks with MS Kermit on them. I took them back to Jacksonville and my friends at a computer distributer that I used to work for built a super computer to load the program onto. It was the latest::: greatest 486::: DX66 with a whopping 32mb of RAM! We dialed in::: anxiously listened to the modem squelch and proceeded to enter what seemed like hundreds of lines of DOS commands. We had the folks back at the computer department on the phone as we successfully registered me for my classes. They cheered as if we just landed on the moon. We had invited clients to witness the technological breakthrough. Amazing how far we've come so fast.

In an intensive 10-day Maymester course::: 14 undergraduate and graduate students in James Beasley‚Äôs wildlife management fieldwork learned how to trap and handle creatures::: both native and invasive::: for study at the Savannah River Ecology Laboratory::: near Aiken::: South Carolina.

Beasley::: an associate professor of wildlife ecology and management in the University of Georgia Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources::: focused on teaching students safe and ethical techniques to study everything from field mice to wild pigs and to survey amphibians and reptiles.

For mammals that were captured for study::: Beasley carefully sedated them before allowing students to gently handle the animals so they could measure vital signs::: take blood and tissue samples::: and remove ticks. Once the animals regained consciousness::: they were released back into their homes.

column4:
I think it‚Äôs disingenuous to have a discussion about vaccine side effects and not mention the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS).

As of April 2::: there have been 2:::342 deaths::: 1:::484 life-threatenin
g adverse events::: 941 cases of permanent disability::: and about 14:::000 hospitalization
s and emergency room visits following COVID vaccination reported to VAERS.

Note that VAERS is a passive surveillance system in the United States that captures adverse events following vaccination::: but is unable to prove causation (i.e. that the vaccine in question caused the adverse event - possible side effect).

You can access this VAERS data yourself by going to the CDC's website and following the steps below: https://
wonder.cdc.gov/
vaers.html

1) Accept disclaimers
2) Click on "VAERS Data Search"
3) Group results by "Event Category"
4) Select "COVID 19 VACCINE" and press "Open"
5) Choose "All Locations"
6) Press "Send"

Or you can also find a more user-friendly summary at: https://
www.openvaers.co
m/covid-data

I would also think that in a discussion about herd immunity::: natural immunity would be mentioned as well as an acknowledgment that these vaccines haven‚Äôt been shown to prevent viral infection or transmission. ‚ÄúBreakthrough cases‚Äù are being reported daily.

In commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the desegregation of the University of Georgia::: the Main Library at UGA is hosting an exhibit that chronicles the historic events of 1961::: when Hamilton Holmes and Charlayne Hunter (now Hunter-Gault) became the first African American students admitted to the university.

column3:
Meanwhile in
1925: Elbert Frank Cox becomes the first black Ph.D. in mathematics::: earning his degree from Cornell University

1931: Jane Matilda Bolin is the first black woman graduate of Yale Law School. She becomes the nation‚Äôs first black woman judge in 1939.

1936: The Maryland Court of Appeals rules that the University of Maryland Law School must admit black applicant Donald Gaines Murray after previously denying him admission based on his race.

1952: The first black student is admitted to the University of Tennessee.

1958: The University of Florida law school admits its first black student::: George Starke Jr.

column3:
It‚Äôs a national disgrace and what UGA parent‚Äôs have been saying all along. I copied and pasted from the WSJ so everyone can read it.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-
Wall Street Journal
The Coronavirus College Scam

My son‚Äôs university invited him back to campus for remote classes at $70:::000 a year. He got a job instead.

By Stephen Moore
Oct. 1::: 2020

My 20-year-old son attends Villanova University. It is a fine school::: but this year it costs $70:::000 a year for room::: board and tuition‚Äîfor online classes. This fall most colleges are charging full tuition to families like mine to have kids on campus without real classrooms. This is like going to a restaurant and never getting served::: but still getting handed the bill.

My son decided to take a pass::: and a full-time job instead. He‚Äôll learn some valuable life skills from that experience::: and he‚Äôll likely go back when classes are back open. But millions of young people are back on campus this fall. In many college towns::: crowded dorms::: fraternities::: sororities and bars are open.

According to one report::: college students represent 19 of the 25 hottest coronavirus outbreaks in the country with some 40:::000 positive cases recorded in September::: so administrators are suspending or even expelling students for irresponsible behaviors like going to crowded parties. But what did college presidents expect when they invited students back?
The silver lining is that almost none of the Covid-positive students have needed hospitalization
::: and most don‚Äôt even get sick. The risk to patients under 30 is minimal. But that doesn‚Äôt absolve the universities for making choices that benefit themselves at the expense of students::: parents and taxpayers::: who foot the bill. The schools collect full tuition while students spread the virus and learn little they couldn‚Äôt by sitting in front of the computer in their parents‚Äô house at a fraction of the cost.
Why? Follow the money. American higher education is a big business::: with total annual revenue of about $600 billion. Last spring::: when schools sent students home midsemester::: few bothered to refund their tuition. They are terrified that kids will save $150:::000 by learning everything they need online::: so education experts have trumpeted the value of the on-campus experience. Students are paying for classes they can‚Äôt attend. Administrators and professors get paid in full even though most refuse to come anywhere near their students.
I‚Äôm proud my son knows a scam when he sees one::: and I hope many of his peers follow his example.

column1: Free surveillance testing for COVID-19 is being offered at Legion Field::: by appointment::: to members of the UGA community who are asymptomatic. The purpose of surveillance testing is to monitor the current state of the pandemic to enable healthcare leaders to plan accordingly. The goal is to test 300 volunteers daily. COVID-19 testing is also offered to students with symptoms at the University Health Center.

When students visit the Ramsey Student Center this fall::: they will notice some changes to the facility and its operations. Face coverings are required::: and cardio and weight equipment have been spread out to maintain social distancing::: just to name a few. Learn more at t.uga.edu/6dF.

I need help sharing the petition for remote instruction for GA Fall 2020 Semester so please check out and share this petition if you agree! I'm having some difficulty advertising with my little power::: so please help: https://
www.change.org/
remoteInstructio
nGAFall2020

With the COVID-19 pandemic still going on::: school is coming back to in-person classes. Seeing the small concern for this issue makes it more stressful and worrying to go back; I live with my grandma who's in the high-risk category::: so I don't want to risk giving her the disease.

I created a petition for prioritizing remote instruction rather than coercing most students to go in person for classes. People who still need to go in would be able to still::: but it would significantly decrease the number of people conglomerating together. I want to help flatten the curve!

column1: In 1962::: Mary Frances Early became the first African American graduate from the University of Georgia when she received her master‚Äôs degree in music education. Fifty-eight years later::: the University of Georgia Mary Frances Early College of Education has been named in her honor and was celebrated at a ceremony back in February. https://t.uga.edu/66S
A quiet campus.

When the COVID-19 pandemic forced nearly 80 students to return home from Italy early::: faculty from the UGA Cortona Studies Abroad program quickly adapted so the students could continue learning from home.

‚ÄúOur faculty really did something that was seemingly impossible. They taught a curriculum of studio art and art history online to students who did not all have access to even the most basic materials::: like brushes and canvases. They accomplished it with an amazing amount of creativity and energy and inspired their students to make the best of the situation.‚Äù

NEWS.UGA.EDU
Studying Abroad at a Distance - Georgia Magazine

cure is colloid silver in water. You can purchase online. I only can recommend Mesosilver brand by Purest Colloids and you can buy direct from them. And::: it is the only brand my Doctor recommends.

You have to take probiotics for a month or two afterward because the silver is non specific and kills everything::: good and bad in your body. Replenishing the good bacteria in your gut can be done over time but you can replace it immediately with probiotics.
The ozone is something that is a natural element in the atmosphere. It is created by lightening::: for example and you may have smelled the ozone after a thunderstorm. The lightning discharge which creates ozone is what cleanses the atmosphere. As the nucleus of the oxygen atom is exposed to the discharge its attraction is magnified and it 'steals' an electron from another atom creating O3. This third electron is very unstable and coming in contact with anything else::: disease germs for example::: that extra electron jumps off the oxygen atom and in the event it is an organic::: as in disease germs::: it instantly electrocutes its new host.

Both these items can be purchased online and FOR LESS THAN $100.00 and be instantly available in the household. The only other thing you need is probiotics::: available at all drug stores::: convenience stores and grocery stores::: over the counter.
To determine if you may have an allergy to the silver particles::: and Ive never heard of one::: simply place a drop on top of your hand and wait five or ten minutes. If there is no reaction::: then you are good to go.
In conclusion::: it is rabidly unbelievable that none of the major health administrators have even mentioned the fact you ear canal is the most vulnerable part of your body for germs to enter! They contain no mucus to help to prevent the germs from entering your body. It is such a simple process to guard against this. Simply put a drop of Mesosilver on a cotton ball and place in your ear. If there is another stimulus fund in the works::: the government could deduct $100.00 and supply every recipient with silver colloids and an ozone machine. column3:
The University of Georgia just cleared their employee Irami Osei-Frimpong::: who is a teacher‚Äôs assistant and a Ph.D. candidate::: of any ‚Äúviolence‚Äù or ‚Äúwrongdoing‚Äù for writing on social media that ‚Äúwhite people may have to die for black communities to be made whole.‚Äù
If there‚Äôs one area where we should be focused on cleaning up::: its schools and universities.
If we don‚Äôt do that ‚Äîin a BIG way‚Äî this is only going to get worse and it will defeat us.
From National File
A Black Lives Matter activist and University of Georgia PhD candidate who currently works at the university as a teaching assistant was cleared by the university following controversial anti-white remarks in which he seemed to advocate political violence.
Irami Osei-Frimpong::: a University of Georgia Ph. D. candidate in philosophy and Black Lives Matter activist::: said that he was under investigation after making an inflammatory social media post where he stated that ‚ÄúSome white people may have to die for black communities to be made whole:::‚Äù and ‚ÄúTo pretend that‚Äôs not the case is ahistorical and generally naive.‚Äù
Osei-Frimpong::: in another post::: wrote ‚ÄúFighting white people is a skill:::‚Äù and after receiving criticism for what seems to be advocacy of political violence::: added that he is ‚Äúconfused why that is so controversial.‚Äù
Though he claims he is not calling for violence::: Osei-Frimpong believed it should still remain as an option when speaking with local media.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a fact of history that racial justice often comes at the cost of white life:::‚Äù the Ph. D. candidate explained. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt advocate for violence. I was just honest of racial progress.‚Äù
However::: according to WBCK::: he wrote the following in a Medium post:
Killing some white people isn‚Äôt genocide; it‚Äôs killing some white people‚Ä¶We had to kill some white people to get out of slavery. Maybe if we‚Äôd killed more during the 20th century we still wouldn‚Äôt talk about racialized voter disenfranchisem
ent and housing::: education::: and employment discrimination.
This should not be controversial.

Here are some of his recent tweets::: which are also dripping with racism and white hate.

This hateful clown will soon be teaching American kids and indoctrinating them with this disgusting and vile hate.
And there are thousands and thousands more just like this Irami character::: both on the front lines and waiting in the wings.
Our schools and universities are churning out racist::: anti-white/
anti-American communist zombie soldiers at an accelerated rate::: and if we don‚Äôt find a way to stop it::: we‚Äôll never recover.

column1:
Time to hunker down::: Bulldogs. Commit to keeping yourselves and our community healthy. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Georgia Football
16 March 2020 –≥.::: 15:15 ¬∑

To all the members of The Bulldog Nation:::

Thank you so much for your continued support during this time. We know that the current events have left us all with a feeling of great uncertainty::: but we will continue to attack each day with a commitment to our community.

Football operations have been suspended. However::: we have a greater mission that extends beyond sport alone. We find ourselves with an opportunity to further our commitment to each other. To direct our passion and energy towards the betterment of our world::: and shelter the family we hold dear. Together::: we will keep each other safe. Football is a team sport. And today::: as members of our team::: we need all of you.

Each one of us has the power to make a difference. To wash our hands regularly. To stay home if we‚Äôre sick::: and safely distance ourselves. To protect. And when this is all over::: we‚Äôll be here::: ready as ever. Be safe. Take care. Call your loved ones. Be a light to your community.

And as always::: Go Dawgs!

- Coach Kirby Smart
